mods:mods.mods:abstract: Acknowledges receipt of two letters, the first introducing Mr. Anstey and the other, dated 7 January, on the powers to be given to Congress. Washington asks whether "the publick mind" is "matured for such an important change as the one you have suggested?....my opinion is, that this Country must yet feel and see more, before it can be accomplished." A thirst for power will take fast hold of the states individually, and those interested in control of state politics will for a formidable phalanx. It is possible that the American system is more perfect in theory than in practice, and that "we shall exhibit the last melancholy proof, that mankind are not competent to their own Government without the means of coercion in the Sovereign." However, Washington would prefer to try the proposed convention as a last means of essaying the practicability of the present form, although such a convention may not be, strictly speaking, legal. Congress can give it a coloring of legality by recommending it. Washington was proposed as a delegate to the convention without his wishes. In a postscript, Washington notes that he has just heard that the Convention will be held in Philadelphia on the second Monday in May.
